<mailto:jhyrryl@gmail.com|jhyrryl@gmail.com>
So Mike, what was it you were saying about templates?
Templates are a huge time saver once you have them, and create a consistent look and feel across your wiki.
You use them for plug n play nav tools, sidebars, etc.
It's been a couple of years, but I've used media wiki on a couple of big projects.
And this is something you have experience with?
yes
Well I don't think the rest of us do, so any work we can do now to make the future easier, we should consider
Thoughts <@U286Q175Y> <@U28TLDP0R>?
Documentation on templates: <https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Help:Templates>
Yeah if mike knows how to do it id love the help
:thumbsup:
And of course, like any re-usable code, templates make it easy to adjust the look and feel of your site without having to manyallyy change everything.
Happy to help.  Is there an aesthetic that you have in mind, or is functionality more important?
I'm a certified scrum master, so I'm happy to just iterate.
I think "wiki" has certain connotations and people expect a certain aesthetic. Maybe we could mirror the MTG wiki
But some people really like their art.
Sure, that's as good a starting point as any.  :slightly_smiling_face:
Thanks, Mike. What do you need from us to get started?
We want the design to match edhrec
Same colors and fonts
access, a list of expected content
not a problem, Don.  :slightly_smiling_face:
How do the templates work? Do we copy and paste text into them easily or would we have to type into them?
I only ask because I wanted to assign a few topics today and let people get working in word documents until the templates are ready if it's easy to paste into them
Once a template is made, it's just markup to use them.
For a lot of template, you're basically just using markup to insert another page.
But the more complicated ones require passing parameters.
What's probably easiest, it to just let people start writing content.
And I'd have people work in the wiki, not in word.
Get them used to the formatting markup
OK, so we can assign people topics but you don't want us writing anything until the templates are done and you train us all on how to use them?
And as with wordpress, if people work offline, it's probably better to do in a notepad-like editor, to avoid copy-paste issues with Word special codes.
No no, go write content. We can backfill those pages to add templates and/or extract content from them to put into templates.
Yeah, if you've got articles to write, write 'em.  :slightly_smiling_face:
And the more pages we have, the easier it is to identity what templates we need to prioritize.
We'll probably want the ParserFunctions extension. <https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Extension:ParserFunctions>
I guess what would be most useful for making templates, is an understanding of the wiki's intended structure, along with the kinds of things you would commonly like to see on a page.
Like, do you expect individual cards to have their own pages?
If so, then I'd expect that there is also a template for displaying a summary of that card info in articles that care about it.
Gotta go for a bit.
So if you go to the Wikipedia page for Magic and edit the source.  <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magic%3A_The_Gathering>

attachments.title: Magic: The Gathering
attachments.text:
Magic: The Gathering is both a trading card and digital collectible card game created by Richard Garfield. Released in 1993 by Wizards of the Coast, Magic was the first trading card game to gain widespread acceptance and it continues to thrive, with approximately twenty million players as of  2015, and over twenty billion Magic cards produced in the period of 2008 to 2016 alone.Magic can be played by two or more players in various formats, which fall into two categories: constructed and limited. Limited formats involve players building a deck spontaneously out of a pool of random cards with a minimum deck size of 40 cards. In constructed, players create decks from cards they own, usually 60 cards with no more than 4 of any given card.  Magic is played in person with printed cards, or using a deck of virtual cards through the Internet-based Magic: The Gathering Online, or on a smartphone or tablet, or through other programs such as Magic: The Gathering Arena.
Each game represents a battle between wizards known as "planeswalkers", who employ spells, artifacts, and creatures depicted on individual Magic cards to defeat their opponents. Although the original concept of the game drew heavily from the motifs of traditional fantasy role-playing games such as Dungeons & Dragons, the gameplay of Magic bears little similarity to pencil-and-paper adventure games, while having substantially more cards and more complex rules than many other card games.
New cards are released on a regular basis through expansion sets.  An organized tournament system played at an international level and a worldwide community of professional Magic players has developed, as well as a substantial secondary market for Magic cards. Certain Magic cards can be valuable due to their rarity and utility in game play, with prices ranging from a few cents to thousands of dollars.

text: All that stuff in double-curly brackets are templates.
At their simplest, they are just chunks of shared text. At their most complex, they're comparable to javascript running on the page.

So it seems likely that we'd have a template for displaying a deck, for example. Rather than having people write [[Card Name]] to make a link to that card's page, we might want a template that's written as {{edh_card|Card Name}} that creates an external link to EDHREC.
installed ParserFunctions extension
